discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
There are 2 versions of this question.
Version 1, missing item: 
Switch2(config-mon-erspan-dst-src)# erspan-id 110
Version 2, missing item:
Switch1(config-mon-src-dst) ip address 10.10.10.10

- You must specify the destination IP address for the ERSPAN traffic in the source session config
- ERSPAN flow ID must match in source and destination sessions.

Selected Answer: D
If you want to be sure D is correct, check question number 569.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
I approve the answer, what is needed:
- Unique session ID
- List of source interfaces or source VLANs that you want to monitor
- What traffic we want to capture: tx, rx or both
- Destination IP address for the GRE tunnel
- Origin IP address which is used as the source for the GRE tunnel
- Unique ERSPAN flow ID

Selected Answer: D
destination IP is mandatory

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must configure an ERSPAN tunnel that mirrors traffic from Linux1 on Switch1 to Linux2 on Switch2. Which command must be added to the destination configuration to enable the ERSPAN tunnel?
Which two namespaces does the LISP network architecture and protocol use? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: EndPoint-Identifyer (EID) and RLOC (Routing Locator) are used to identify hosts in LISP architecture, to where send traffic.
Answer is correct

Selected Answer: BE
B & E are correct

Selected Answer: BE
B y E son las correctas
Rloc are the region locator and the EID is the endpoint identifer

Ref: IP Routing: LISP Configuration Guide, Cisco IOS XE Release 3S

“C H A P T E R 1
Locator ID Separation Protocol (LISP) Overview

Locator ID Separation Protocol (LISP) is a network architecture and protocol that implements the use of two namespaces instead of a single IP address:

• Endpoint identifiers (EIDs)—assigned to end hosts.
• Routing locators (RLOCs)—assigned to devices (primarily routers) that make up the global routing system.
…”

A. TLOC

Wrong answer.

B. RLOC

Correct answer.

C. DNS

Wrong answer.

D. VTEP

Wrong answer.

E. EID

Correct answer.

Selected Answer: BE
voting. provided answer is correct

Where did the Cisco exams gone? Can't find any in the site anymore.

A. 
ciscoasa(config)# access-list MAIL_AUTH extended permit udp any any eq http 
ciscoasa(config)# aaa authentication listener http outside redirect

B. 
ciscoasa(config)# access-list MAIL_AUTH extended permit tcp any any eq www 
ciscoasa(config)# aaa authentication listener http inside redirect

C. 
ciscoasa(config)# access-list MAIL_AUTH extended permit tcp any any eq http 
ciscoasa(config)# aaa authentication listener http inside port 43

D. 
ciscoasa(config)# access-list HTTP_AUTH extended permit udp any any eq http 
ciscoasa(config)# aaa authentication listener http outside port 43

comments.content: The inside network in our example consists of the TACACS+ server and the storage server. Everything else is part of the outside.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Option 'C' & 'D' are incorrect, because HTTP uses port number 80.
Option 'B' is incorrect, because we want to authenticate outside HTTP traffic against an internal web page (by requesting a username, & a password,) before redirecting traffic to the internet.
"inside" is used for traffic originating from our local LAN (storage server)
"outside" is used for traffic originating from outside of our local LAN (remote users, or any other user on the internet).

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa72/configuration/guide/conf_gd/fwaaa.html#:~:text=the%20following%20commands%20authenticate%20all%20inside%20HTTP%20traffic

B is correct.
just a strong feeling no idea why

Selected Answer: B

Selected Answer: B
See: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa72/configuration/guide/conf_gd/fwaaa.html

Selected Answer: B
B is the only one that makes any sense - eq www is correct to allow tcp port 80.
